description:
Currently swap_xapi_host() only use replace() to change the hostname of original url, but this could not deal with the situation like:

swap_xapi_host("http://hostname:port/hostname", 'otherserver')

Should use the result of urlparse to create a new result with the host changed, and then use urlunparse()
title: xenapi: swap_xapi_host should use urlunparse to create new url

comments.content:
Currently swap_xapi_host() only use replace() to change the hostname of original url, but this could not deal with the situation like:

swap_xapi_host("http://hostname:port/hostname", 'otherserver')

Should use the result of urlparse to create a new result with the host changed, and then use urlunparse()
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~qiaowei-ren

comments.content:
Fix proposed to branch: master
Review: https://review.openstack.org/285738
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hudson-openstack

comments.content:
How might a XAPI URL ever include http://hostname:port/hostname ? The URL is either to http or https (I've never even seen it on a differnt port; that's quite hard to set up)

I think this is proposing to add complexity and I don't understand the justification
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~bob-ball

comments.content:
Change abandoned by Tin Lam (<email address hidden>) on branch: master
Review: https://review.openstack.org/285738
Reason: Duplicated effort.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~hudson-openstack

comments.content:
@Bob, I just mean that the string of "hostname" could appear repeatedly in the URL, and so we could not just use "url.replace()" to replace all the string same to "hostname". And This will be fragile. 

We should use urlunparse() to make new URL.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~qiaowei-ren

comments.content:
Hi Ren,  I understand the theory but I don't believe there is any way it could occur in practice.

The URL is to connect to XAPI and I don't see any way that a XAPI URL could possibly include the hostname in the URL part as well.

A generic URL could, but a XAPI connection URL could not.

Bob
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~bob-ball

comments.content: Bob, you mean that XAPI address could not be like "http://myserver:port/otherstring/..."? It is only like http://myserver:port, right?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~qiaowei-ren

comments.content:
That's right.  The connection URL is served by XAPI and doesn't support having a path for the connection url after the port.

Some paths (e.g. /import) do exist, but they cannot be used for connection strings and you must already have a valid connection to use them (you need to pass the session ID to /import)
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~bob-ball

comments.content: @Bob, I got it. If so, this will not be a bug for Xen case. In addition, is it possible if we connect to xenapi with "unix://local" but local node is slave of the any cluster?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~qiaowei-ren

comments.content:
In theory, yes, it's theoretically possible to use the unix://local URL to connect to a slave - however I don't think we can rely on having a routable connection to the master in this case.
I'm very happy for host aggregate / pool-based connections to be IP-based only rather than using the local unix socket.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~bob-ball
